thread.title: Sasser: Custom vehicles, ideal for rugged terrain, are worth the 3-year wait
thread.title_full: Sasser: Custom vehicles, ideal for rugged terrain, are worth the 3-year wait | Dallas Morning News

author: Ray Sasser
title: Sasser: Custom vehicles, ideal for rugged terrain, are worth the 3-year wait
text:
John Lannom has built ranch buggies in Fort Stockton since 1975. He's never advertised his product, never put up a billboard on a highway, never had a website. Most of the time, Lannom doesn't even answer the shop phone.
If you order a buggy today, it would be ready in about three years. Lannom has 40 of these Texas-popular vehicles on order. You could also buy one of Lannom's ranch buggies Thursday at the Treasure Street Auction benefiting Scottish Rite Hospital for Children.
Full details about the event at Old Parkland are online at treasurestreet.com.
Lannom donates a ranch buggy to the Treasure Street Auction every year. One of them sold for a record $61,000.
"The basic buggy that I sell costs $15,000 and it goes up from there, depending on the options," said Lannom. "I think the most expensive one that I've built was $22,000. I can put dog boxes on them for quail hunters. I can add a top and a winch and extra seats, just about anything you want. I painted one pink for a lady bird hunter."
Some West Texas ranchers own as many as 15 of Lannom's buggies, which are something of an ATV with a Volkswagen soft-ride suspension and a Volkswagen air-cooled engine. They're two-wheel drive but still capable of going just about anywhere another motorized vehicle might bravely or foolishly venture.
Lannom donated a buggy to Texas A&M's wildlife research program. Dale Rollins calls it "the pride of the A&M fleet." Graduate students use it for traveling to research sites around the rugged Rolling Plains Quail Research Ranch in Fisher County (west of Abilene). Rollins is ranch director. He liked the buggy so much he bought one three years ago.
"I love to have my buggy in some rough country with a new rider, hit the gas, and watch them reach for something to hang onto," said Rollins. "Once we've crossed the rough spot, I will point out that they could have sipped a martini and not dripped a drop."
The secret, said both Lannom and Rollins, is the suspension, built soft enough for a comfortable ride but tough enough to take a daily beating on West Texas ranches so big their size is often described in sections (640 acres) rather than acres.
Ranchers use them for work once done by horseback and also to save wear and tear on heavy-duty pickup trucks that cost $60,000 or more.
Lannom once sold a buggy to a rancher who'd gotten too old to ride horses. The rancher's son later told Lannom that the buggy had extended his father's active life by 10 years. Though Lannom figures the vehicle's top speed at about 50 mph, the old rancher claimed 65 mph for his.
Rollins recalls having his buggy stuck twice, both times in deep mud. He was able to winch it out.
"If you get hung up on a rock, you take a pry bar, scoot the buggy over a little and go again," he said. "They're pretty incredible."
Each buggy is built by hand, often welded and otherwise assembled by local kids. Lannom has hired them as young as 12 and taught them the fine points of welding and auto mechanics. One youngster, busy in school and in athletics after school, came to work each day at 3 a.m. and worked until it was time for class. His dad drove him to work because he was too young for a driver's license.
Lannom, 68, plans to continue his tradition of donating a ranch buggy to the Treasure Street auction. He personally knows families who have benefited from the Scottish Rite Hospital for Children.
"Every year, I get thank-you notes from kids, parents, grandparents, aunts, uncles, all thanking me for the donation," he said. "When you think about the kids you're helping, it makes the work worthwhile."
CALENDAR SATURDAY, OCT. 17 : Optimist Club of Grand Prairie's annual Big Bass Bonanza Tournament benefiting the youth of Grand Prairie. Details: optimistgp.org.
TUESDAY, OCT. 20 : Dallas Fly Fishers fly-tying classes at Cabela's in Allen. First of four classes offered from 6:30 p.m.-8 p.m, featuring six expert tyers at separate tables to instruct on tying warm, cold and saltwater patterns. Materials provided for a nominal fee. Details: Richard Johnson at 469-877-0695.
WEDNESDAY, OCT. 21 : First split of South Zone dove season ends.
FRIDAY, OCT. 23 : Texas Shootout sporting clays event benefiting the Rob Harper Memorial Fund. Registration beginning at noon at Elm Fork Shooting Range. Details: Melissa Reddick at mreddick@fcdallas.com or 469-365-0147.
SATURDAY, OCT. 24 : The Dallas Fly Fishers will teach the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department (TPWD) Fly Fishing Instructor Course at Cabela's in Allen. Participants will learn the requirements for teaching fly fishing classes and become certified to teach the TPWD course. Free, 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Register by calling Richard Johnson at 469-877-0695. Details: dallasflyfishers.org.
SATURDAY, OCT. 24-SUNDAY, OCT. 25 : Youth-only duck hunting weekend in High Plains Mallard Management Unit and South Zone.
SUNDAY, OCT. 25 : First split of dove season ends in North and Central Zones.
SATURDAY, OCT. 31 : Quail season begins statewide; South Zone duck season begins; West Zone goose season begins.
SATURDAY, OCT. 31-SUNDAY, NOV. 1 : Youth-only deer hunting weekend, statewide; youth-only duck hunting weekend in the North Zone; first split of duck season in High Plains Mallard Management Unit.
MONDAY, NOV. 2 : Dallas Fly Fishers monthly meeting at the Wyndham Hote, 7800 Alpha Road, Dallas. Casual dinner and social hour at 6 p.m. with the program at 7 p.m. on trout fishing in Colorado by Pat Dorsey. Details: dallasflyfishers.org or call Richard Johnson at 469-877-0695.
FRIDAY, NOV. 6 : East Zone goose season begins; second split of High Plains Mallard Management Unit duck season begins.
SATURDAY, NOV. 7 : General white-tailed deer season begins statewide; North Zone duck season begins.
SATURDAY, NOV. 7 : Fly fishing class conducted by the Dallas Fly Fishers at the Lewisville Lake Environmental Learning Area, Jones and Kealy Street, Lewisville, 8:30 a.m.-3 p.m. Course covers casting, fly tying, knots, entomology, regulations and ethics. The course is free, but there is a $5 per car entry fee to the LLELA. Pre-registration required. Call Richard Johnson at 469-877-0695 to register.
THURSDAY, NOV. 12 : Dallas Ducks Unlimited Fundraising Banquet and Auction at the Centennial Hall at Fair Park. Doors open at 5 p.m. Details: DallasDucks.org.
FRIDAY, DEC. 18 : Second split of dove season begins statewide.
